item.title: Spencer LaVere Smith
item.description: The Diesel2p system (25 mm^2 field-of-view) has an 8 mm working distance air objective.That big air working distance is nice, it also lets a lot of light in from the sides. And we care about that because we use visual stimulation in our projects.Fortunately, PhD student Joe Canzano made a nice 3D printed cap for the objective that fits to the head plates that we use. You can customize it for yours.More pictures and photos are on the Nemonic discussion board: https://neuromatch.social/@sls/112629868836444772

item.title: Boris Barbour
item.description: An unusually sensitive and complete write-up of the collateral damage in a misconduct affair. It really highlights the waste of other people's time and damaged careers that unreliable research can cause, while the perpetrator gains the job and the grants. In other cases there might also be downstream medical or policy effects. And here it was only discovered because the raw data were still available. A more careful cheat could probably have better covered their tracks.https://www.thetransmitter.org/science-and-society/a-scientific-fraud-an-investigation-a-lab-in-recovery/?utm_source=mastodon&utm_medium=org-social&utm_campaign=20241004-a-scientific-fraud

item.title: Kristin
item.description: "Nearly 50% of researchers quit science within a decade, huge study reveals" https://doi.org/10.1038/d41586-024-03222-7Interesting study but I think Nature's headline is more sensationalized than accurate. The study counted who kept publishing in the years after their first publication.Under that metric, I'm still a scientist (I publish in librarianship now) but my husband (a chemist who worked in R&D) is not?Interesting study but it's not a measure of who claims the title "scientist".
